text: We don't know what we're looking at.  It's an abstract mass -- swirling lines in constant motion -- but we're to close to see any form. As WE PULL BACK, we can now make out that they are what seem like animated streaks of charcoal -- forming and reforming into a series of drawings: First, a small girl, clutching a rag doll.  She stares plaintively into the lens as around the edges of the frame, a male figure with a thick, black moustache, cradles her protectively in his arms. But this image quickly changes to a landscape -- evil and foreboding.  A desolate farmhouse against an overcast sky Leafless trees with spiky tentacles for branches sprout like eruptions from the very bowels of hell.  It's every shade of gray -- ominous, depraved. Now we start to close in on this landscape's heart of darkness -- a constricted old corn crib -- but before we get close enough to see inside it, the scene shifts.  A pale, sad-eyed teenage girl looking straight at us.  Then we move to a line drawing of the rag doll that the little girl had clutched earlier -- only now it hangs from a noose, surrounded by long, shattered lines that recall th farmhouse branches.  The last shift leads us to a dark haired little boy, scared into impenetrable silence, as h is approached from behind by the immense, leering presence of an adult male. Finally, this Rotoscope animated picture transform itself into reality -- an actual oil painting, wet and glistenin on a canvas.  It's the first image we've seen that has dimension or texture.  In a moment, a paint-stained hand enters the frame and feverishly smears the adult figure beyond all recognition with its fingers, leaving the little boy alone in the F.G.  Then, the hand leaves, returning with a paint brush.  It re-does the area surrounding the child in a wash of midnight blue.  As it does, we hear:
He had some kind of stain or something on his hands.
Stain?  What, like dirt?
Oil?
No.  They were blue.  Dark blue. All over his fingers.
Ink?
No.  I don't know what it was.  But it had a funny smell to it.

DONNA WEST is a short, plump woman in her twenties, eyes red from crying, hair in her face, talking to POLICE CHIE KLEBERG and DETECTIVE BOXERBAUM.  She's huddled across a table from them in a blanket.  Beside her stands a FEMALE POLICE OFFICER.

head_text.subj: A LEGEND COMES UP ON SCREEN

text: Oh, God, I don't know.  I can't think.
Alright, don't worry about his hands.  Just try and tell us whatever you remember so that we can get a statement.
It was about eight A.M. and I was getting out of my car in the parking lot.
This is at Ohio State?
Yes, I'm an optometry student there.
DONNA WEST is getting out of her beat up Toyota.  We see what she describes.

I had gone around to the passenger side to pick up some books, and as I was leaning in... BILLY MILLIGAN, a regular looking guy, maybe a little burlier than average, with a full mustache and brown tinted sunglasses, enters frame.  He holds a small revolver, which he presses against DONNA'S arm.

Would you please get in the car? Frightened, she does.  BILLY goes around to the driver's side and gets in.  He takes out a pair of handcuffs and cuffs her to the inside of the door.  He goes through her bag and pulls out her car keys.  He starts the car and drives off.
As they drive away from the campus.
Where are we going? But BILLY is muttering to himself, oblivious to her question.
I know this is gonna sound ridiculous, but I have an optometry test today... He looks at her suddenly.
You can study for it if you want. This won't take long.  Go on. She picks up a text book with her trembling free hand and feigns studying.
As the car drives through a deserted stretch of countryside.
DONNA is "studying" stealing glances at BILLY.  Suddenly, BILLY grabs her bag and pulls out her address book.  As h rips out pages.
I'm taking these addresses and phone numbers.  If you say anything to the police, I'll send someone from my brotherhood after you.
KLEBERG and BOXERBAUM.
His "brotherhood"?
But now we see they're not talking to DONNA WEST, they're talking to CARRIE DRYER -- a prettier GIRL also in her twenties, also very upset.  There's a sketch artist there
That's what he said.  He belonged to a brotherhood and they'd send someone after me if I said anything.
Was he high?  Could you tell?
It's weird.  There was liquor on his breath... I mean he reeked... but he drove perfectly.  In fact, he didn't act drunk at all, except when he would talk to himself.
(holds up a sketch of Billy)
How's this?
He didn't have a moustache.  He was clean shaven.
BILLY is now clean shaven, driving through the woods. Handcuffed to the passenger door is CARRIE DRYER.  BILLY is muttering to himself.  He wears sunglasses.
As it bumps over train tracks.
The jostling seems to jar him back to reality.  He turns on CARRIE.
Take off your pants.
What?
Take your fucking pants off! She does the best she can with only one hand.
You won't run away without any pants on.
The car is parked.  BILLY and CARRIE stand beside it -- she is in a blouse and underwear.
(gently)
Are you cold? She shakes her head "no".  BILLY lays CARRIE'S buckskin jacket down on the muddy ground.
(awkwardly, not looking at her)
Take off your underwear and lay down. CARRIE dissolves in tears.
KLEBERG and BOXERBAUM.
(offers Kleenex)
It's O.K.  You want to stop for a while?
A different WOMAN is there, taking the Kleenex to wipe he eyes.  It is POLLY NEWTON, a little younger than the othe two.
No.  I'm all right.
Did he hit you or push you or hurt you in any way?
No.  He wrote me a poem.
A poem?
(nods)
A love poem.  He never showed it to me because he was afraid you'd trace his handwriting.
POLLY lies on the ground, naked from the waist down. BILLY crumples up a piece of paper, then slides next to her and holds her gently like one would a lover.

Do you know what it's like to be lonely?  Not to be held by anyone? Not to know the meaning of love? He looks at her and takes off his sunglasses.  His eyes repeatedly drift slowly to one side, then dart back to center.
DONNA WEST and the two cops.
It's called nystagmus.  I'm an optometry student.  I recognized it immediately.  An involuntary oscillation of the eyeballs.
CARRIE DRYER and the two cops.
He never took off his glasses.  I don't know.
Then what happened? CARRIE breaks down.
He... raped... me...
BILLY on top of CARRIE.  We don't see much, but it's obvious what is going on.
DONNA WEST staring straight off into space.
BILLY on top of DONNA.  She stares off exactly as she had in the police station.
The FEMALE POLICE OFFICER holding POLLY, who is crying uncontrollably.
BILLY holding POLLY tightly after the rape.  They are bot standing half-dressed.
I'm sorry we had to meet under these circumstances.  I really love you. His eyes drift and dart.  He puts on his sunglasses.
POLLY NEWTON and the OFFICERS.
Then he drove me back into town and made me cash him a check at my bank.
(to Boxerbaum)
Same as the others.
Then he took me to Wendy's.
Wendy's?
For a burger. The COPS give each other a look.
DONNA WEST and the OFFICERS.
Then we finally went back to the campus and he left.  Oh yeah -- he said his name was Phil.
thud down onto the table
to include CARRIE DRYER and the OFFICERS.
There's this many criminals around here?
That's just the young, white male sex offenders.  And only the ones who've been arrested. CARRIE starts going through the photos.
going through photos.  She comes to one of BILLY, wearing mutton chops.  She stops.  The OFFICERS react.
It sure looks like him... but I can't be sure. DONNA, KLEBERG and BOXERBAUM.
(jumps up, knocking over her chair)
That's him.  No doubt about it.  I'm positive. KLEBERG picks it up and WE PRESS IN on a name: WILLIAM STANLEY MILLIGAN.

It looks like an embassy under siege.  Uniformed COPS with dogs comb the area.  Armed COPS keep watch from ever roof top.  Flashlights dart everywhere -- occasionally illuminating posters of the police sketch of BILLY on campus walls and windows.  In their dorm rooms, frightene GIRLS watch from their windows, while below MALE CO-EDS travel in packs with baseball bats.  A newspaper vending machine shows the Columbus Dispatch headline: CAMPUS RAPIST MANHUNT CONTINUES - POLICE URGE CURFEW.
A two story apartment complex.  Three unmarked police car pull up in front.
BOXERBAUM driving, a young PLAIN CLOTHES OFFICER in the passenger seat.

5673 Old Livingston.  That's his current address. The YOUNG OFFICER checks his weapon, puts it back in the waistband of his pants, then puts on a Domino Pizza hat and grabs a pizza box from the back seat.

TWO OFFICERS carefully approach the rear of BILLY'S groun floor apartment.  One looks in a window.  He can't see anyone, but the floor of the living room is covered with kids toys: blocks, trucks, etc.  Then we hear voices.  We can't make out what they're saying, but It's some kind of argument between three men: one with an English accent, one with some sort of Eastern European accent, and one American mid-west.
Shit.  He's not alone.
As the YOUNG OFFICER rings the bell. In a moment, BILLY answers the door.
Pizza.  You Billy Milligan?
Who?
Billy Milligan?  5673 Old Livingston?
I'm not Billy Milligan and I didn't order any pizza.
As BOXERBAUM watches from a distance -- his hand on his gun.
You're sure you're not William Stanley Milligan?
Huh? The YOUNG OFFICER throws the pizza up into BILLY'S face and pulls out his gun, holding it against his head.
Freeze.  Police Officer.
What's going on? COPS are suddenly everywhere.  Bursting in through the back door, piling out of cars, all with guns drawn.
Where the TWO OFFICERS who heard voices are barreling through, expecting an ambush.
He's not alone!
Alright, motherfuckers, come on out! THE YOUNG OFFICER grabs BILLY and turns him around.  Usin BILLY'S body as a shield, he drags him through the apartment, looking for accomplices.
kick the closet door, then the bathroom door -- all empty
steps on a LEGGO fort -- crushing it.
grabs a Smith and Wesson nine millimeter from under a chair in the living room.
Where are they?
Who?  There's no one here.

finds several paintings.  He moves one and reveals the picture of the little boy we saw being worked on earlier. BOXERBAUM enters frame.  It clicks.  He goes over to BILL and yanks his fingers open.  They're completely paint stained.
finds wallets, cash and I.D.'s on top of a dresser.  He picks up two credit cards and a drivers license belonging to Carrie Dryer.  Donna West and Polly Newton, respectively.
(as he cuffs Billy)
William Milligan, you're under arrest.  You have the right to remain silent... (etc.)
As we PRESS IN on BILLY.

As a police truck pulls up.  TWO GUARDS open the rear doors and out steps a group of PRISONERS, all handcuffed to each other -- except for BILLY, who pops out free as a bird, giving the GUARDS the finger.  The BLACK PRISONER who had been cuffed to him is panicked.
I didn't do nothin' I swear I didn't do nothin' ONE GUARD holds BILLY while the other re-cuffs him.

TV CAMERAS and REPORTERS everywhere, demanding information.  POLICE CHIEF KLEBERG makes his way through the chaos without answering them.  We FOLLOW him into a room where TWO OFFICERS are unloading a carton onto a table.  It is filled with every make weapon imaginable.
Jesus Christ.  It's a fucking arsenal.
BILLY sits in the middle of the floor drawing a picture. It's simple, childish.  TWO GUARDS watch him from the other side of the bars.  One holds a cup.  The other bang the bars with his nightstick.
Hey, Jew Boy.
What do you know -- we have a goddamn Rembrandt on our hands.
Maybe he can draw himself a new asshole after the cons at Lima get through humpin' the one he's got. They don't look too kindly on rapists over there.
They sent you down some Kool-Aid. You want it? BILLY looks up.
Is that a no? The GUARD starts to turn away, but BILLY gets up.  He comes to the bars and reaches for the cup.  The GUARD grabs his wrist and pulls.
Hey, you think we oughta tattoo this Jew Boy?
Yeah.  Put some numbers right there. BILLY pulls his arm free as the GUARDS laugh.

Here ya go, Rembrandt. He throws the drink onto BILLY'S picture, ruining it. Instantly, BILLY changes.  His eyes, his gait.  His chest expands and his adrenaline flows a mile a minute as he gets up and walks over to the toilet bowl.  He squats and grabs hold of it.  The GUARDS give each other a look, the eye him warily.  Sweat pours down as he focuses his strength till it's like the pinpoint of a laser.  Then, with a mighty heave he rips the toilet from the wall, stands and hurls it at the GUARDS in one impossible motion.  It smashes into a million pieces -- porcelain shards fly into the GUARD'S faces, cutting them to ribbons.
BILLY being beaten senseless by SIX GUARDS as they put hi into a straitjacket.
BILLY is nearly unconscious as the GUARDS drag him down the narrow hallway -- laying into him the entire way.
They throw BILLY in.  His head hits the cement hard as th cell door slams shut behind him with a thunderous echo.
KLEBERG in front of a phalanx of microphones, reading a statement.
We do have a suspect in custody. His name is William Stanley Milligan.  He has one prior conviction from a run-in with a prostitute.
A GUARD carries a tray of food toward BILLY'S cell.
We continue to treat this investigation very carefully and very thoroughly but with the evidence we've already gathered, we feel extremely confident. The GUARD reaches the cell door.  As he opens it.
O.K., rapist, chow time.  We all took turns spitting in your food before I brought it down, but you can ignore that, can't ya?  Just pretend it's soup... His eyes suddenly go wide.
Jesus H. Christ.
BILLY is fast asleep in the middle of his cell.  He is ou of the straitjacket and is using it as a pillow.  And he' sucking his thumb.
Open and shut.  A textbook investigation.
DR. ADAM FINK, a clinical psychologist, sits across a table from BILLY.

head_text.subj: TIGHT ON A PAGE OF NOTES

text: At the top of the page, beside BILLY'S vital statistics, DR. FINK fills in his name.  Underneath, he writes: PRELIMINARY REPORT.
on them both, DR. FINK just watches for a moment.  BILLY is withdrawn and out of it, like a boxer who's taken one too many left hooks.  There's a wall between him and the world.
Do you know why you're here, Billy? No response.
Under COMMENTS, the DOCTOR writes: eyes completely normal No evidence of nystagmus.
Billy?
(snaps back slightly)
Oh.
Do you know why you're here?
No.
Did you understand what the police officers said when you were arrested?
The... what?
Do you know why you've been arrested?  Billy? He just stares blankly.  DR. FINK writes.
DR. FINK is adding: SULLEN; NON-COMMUNICATIVE; TOTALLY DISORIENTED.
suddenly energetic, even hyper -- night and day to the wa we've just seen him.
(laughing)

You should have seen their fuckin' faces when them van doors opened and BOOM!.  There I am, out of the cuffs and givin' them the finger.  Shit... Whassamatter, Doc, not actin' crazy enough for ya?  How's this? He rubs his lips up and down with his finger and makes a "crazy" sound.  As he does:
to reveal he's talking to DR. RICHARD EDMUNDS, in the sam room, some time later.  EDMUNDS holds DR. FINK'S report and is completely confused.  BILLY laughs.  Then:
Who do you have to fuck to get somethin' to eat around here?  I'm starving.  And a lawyer might be nice.  What do you say?

Next to DR. FINK'S report, we see DR. EDMUNDS' hand fill in his own report.  He's already put down his name, BILLY'S name and underneath written: FOLLOW UP REPORT. Now we see him writing: OUTGOING, OBNOXIOUS, TOTALLY COHERENT AND AWARE.  EYES NORMAL.

The novelty's wearin' thin, you know what I mean?  I been in places worse than this in my life, and I'll tell you something... there isn't a box on Earth can hold me.  Certainly not this two bit, rinky dink drunk tank.
I'd like to talk to you about the attacks.

Hey, I wasn't there.  I don't know what they're talkin' about because I didn't do a fuckin' thing they accused me of.  And I don't lie. Using his right hand.  BILLY starts doodling a sketch of landscape on the table with a marker.  EDMUNDS looks at him quizzically.

I want to play a little game.  Write down the first thing that comes into your mind. He moves a pen and a piece of paper toward BILLY, who writes with his right hand.  EDMUNDS looks at the information on his form.
Scan down BILLY'S listed vital statistics -- Hair: Brown; Eyes: Brown; Height: six feet; Weight: 175; Birthdate: 2- 14-55; etc. until he gets to: Left Handed.
He hands back the paper.  It says: I AM INNOCENT.

head_text.subj: TIGHT ON THE PREVIOUS TWO REPORTS

text: On DR. EDMUNDS, "Left Handed" has been crossed out and "Right Handed" written in.  Next to them is a third form, with the NAME: DR. CLAIRE HUBBARD and SUPERVISOR'S REPORT written underneath.
The same room.  DR. HUBBARD, hopelessly confused, and BILLY, who now appears to be a frightened child.  Fragile Near tears.  Knees drawn up into a fetal position in the chair.
Are you alright?  You look like you're about to fall apart.
I'm scared.
There's nothing to be scared of. I'm Dr. Hubbard from the Southwest Community Mental Health Center and I'm here to ask you a few questions. Where are you currently living?
Here.
What's your Social Security number?
I don't know.
I don't know.
Billy, if I'm going to help you, you're going to have to try and...
Billy's asleep.
What?
Billy's asleep.  And the others don't want me to wake him up.
What others?
The other people.  They want Billy to stay asleep.
Who are these other people?
I can't talk about it.  I made a mistake telling you.  Promise you won't say anything to anyone.
I promise.  But you have to tell me...
(upset)
I can't...
Alright, you don't have to say anything else, but would you do me a favor?
What?
Would you sign your name for me?
She gives him a pen and paper.  He takes it into his left hand and scrawls in a child's penmanship: DANNY.

location: HALL OUTSIDE OF SAME DRAB WHITE ROOM

text: Through the door, we see BILLY, alone, waiting.  Outside, DR. HUBBARD and JUDY STEVENSON, a public defense attorney, are talking.
Multiple personality disorder?  You mean like Sybil?
Worse -- if one of the personalities is a violent criminal.

With all respect, Doctor, if you were a rapist, caught dead to rights with a ton of evidence in your apartment, wouldn't you try and make up a story, too?  Trust me, this is a guy who read a bestseller and got a brainstorm.
Maybe, but I don't think so.  He's already been seen by three separate doctors because no one could make head of tails of him.
Well, I thought I'd seen it all, but I have to admit "I didn't do it, he did" "No I didn't" "Yes he did" -- that's a new one even to me.
Just come in and talk to him with me -- then decide.
We'll represent him no matter what. We have to.  But fine-- (as they go in)
I only have a caseload that high sitting on my desk while I waste a whole afternoon here...

The first thing we hear is reggae music: Bob Marley's "Jammin", with a male voice that can't really sing, singing along.  Then we PAN along the office -- a royal mess -- books, papers everywhere -- a poster of the BILL OF RIGHTS with "NULL AND VOID WHERE PROHIBITED BY LAW" stamped across it in red letters.  We finally come to a big, bear-like figure in an ex-hippie's khaki shirt and jeans -- late thirties, with a beard and an oversized stogie, skankin' around the office.  This is GARY SCHWEICKART.
(in a Jamaican accent)
Ladies and gentlemen of the jury, my client, Jah Skank Irie, is innocent. For it is not the ganja weed that is on trial here today, only the man... mon. JUDY burst in.
Gary, put down what you're doing and get your ass down to Franklin with me.
(Jamaican accent)
Whoa -- don't get your knickers in a twist -- you'll give yourself one of them aneurisms.
I'm serious, Gary.  I think you should see this. She dumps her notes on his desk.
(drops the accent)
Billy Milligan?
Yes.

Uh uh.  Sorry, Judy, one of the perks of getting to be the boss is you don't have to give up all your free time representing the Campus Rapist if you don't want to.  And I don't want to.  Besides, I already met him before I ordered the psychiatric evaluation, and he specifically asked for a female lawyer.
(smiles, she knows he's  gonna like this)
He's not guilty.
(he does, his eyes twinkle, he loves a challenge)
Not guilty?  They got enough hard evidence to lock him up till doomsday.
(leans in)
I'm telling you, Billy Milligan did not commit those rapes.  At least come down and talk to him. A beat.  GARY leaps up, grabs his beret to leave.

JUDY, GARY and BILLY.  BILLY has withdrawn completely int himself -- eyes half-closed, his lips moving in some internal conversation.  JUDY looks at GARY, who just sits there -- skeptical and impassive.  Finally, BILLY opens his eyes and is suddenly infused with the same belligeren energy he had while talking to DR. EDMUNDS.
(to Judy)
Who's Ranger Bob?
This is Gary Schweickart.  He works with me in the Public Defenders office.
Howdy, Bob. GARY smiles tightly.  He doesn't like him right off.
You don't remember meeting him briefly when you first came in?
(shakes his head)
That's not a face you forget.
I know that you requested a female attorney, but Gary's the most qualified...
I didn't request nothin'
Well, Billy did.
Billy's asleep.
(getting annoyed)
Well, someone did.
(imitates Gary)
Well, someone ain't me.
Who are you?
Tommy.
And have we met before?
Yeah.  You came in with one of the headshrinkers.
And at that time you answered to the name Billy?
We all do.  Saves time.  But that don't mean we like it.
Alright... Tommy... we'd like to ask you a few questions.  How old are you?
Sixteen.
How much time do you spend as Billy? Were you there when he got out of the straitjacket?
(laughs)
Yeah, that was me.  Billy couldn't get out of a wet paper bag.  I can dislocate my shoulder to slip it down to where I can loosen the ties.
Where'd you learn to do that? BILLY looks away.
Tommy?
You got somethin' else you wanna know or can I leave?
No.  Please.  How many of you live there with Billy? BILLY smiles.
More than three?  More than five?
I'm not really sure.  A lot.
Were you there when... whoever you were at the time was arrested?
No.  That was Danny.
The little boy.
Danny's the keeper of pain.
What does that mean?
College man, Bob?  Ivy League? GARY steams.
It means whenever Billy's in any pain, Danny comes onto the spot to take it.
The spot?  What's that?
Jesus Christ... it's not my job to answer all these questions.  I'm outta here.
No, wait... Tommy... But BILLY has retreated into himself once again.  Eyes glazed and half-closed -- lips moving silently.
This is what you dragged me here for in the middle of the day?

Wait. In a moment, BILLY "returns" -- but now he sits with impeccable posture, his fingertips pressed together in front of him.  He speaks in clipped, precise tones with a perfect Knightsbridge English accent.
I must apologize for Tommy's impudence.  He gets frustrated from being locked up.  My name is Arthur. How do you do? JUDY and GARY exchange a look.  He ain't buying it.
How do you do? JUDY looks again at GARY, who half rolls his eyes.
(mutters)
Yeah, how are ya...
Well, understandably, I've been better.  But Tommy said you have some questions.
Yes.  Gary was asking about the arrest.
The police found an arsenal of weapons in your apartment.
I have nothing to do with those. The only one permitted to handle guns is Ragen.  He's the Keeper of Rage.
He used those guns when he kidnapped and raped those three women.
(icily calm)

Ragen never raped anyone.  He committed the robberies because we were skint, but he denies, absolutely, having anything to do sexually with those women.  And of the many things he undoubtedly is, a liar is not among them.  All our lives people have accused us of being liars.  It's become a point of honor never to tell a falsehood.
But if you don't always volunteer the truth, then that's lying by omission.

Oh come now.  As an attorney, you know very well a witness is under no compulsion to volunteer information he hasn't been asked for.  You would be the first one to tell a client not to elaborate unless it was in his best interest. But why don't you meet Ragen and ask him yourself?
Isn't Ragen the one who pulled the toilet from the wall and threw it at the guards?
He's learned to control his flow of adrenaline.  It gives him unnatural strength. (playfully)
But don't worry -- he won't hurt you. Unless, of course, he feels threatened.

Alright... Arthur -- I'd like to meet him. BILLY smiles -- then gets up and moves his chair to the far side of the room -- putting as much distance between himself and them as possible.  He sites back down and the retreats once more.  Eyes look down -- lips move.
How much education has he had?
Not much.  Some high school.  D average.  I.Q.'s a hundred.  He paints, though.
Paints?

Portraits, landscapes.  He's good. Then, BILLY'S back.  He seems bigger -- hulking -- crouched like a wary fighter.  The tension in his facial muscles change his appearance.  His eyes squint narrowly, giving them a piercing quality -- his brow beetles.  And he speaks in a thick, Slavic accent.
Who called me a liar?
(a little unnerved)
I said the evidence indicated that someone in there raped those three woman.
I admit three robberies near university.  But other things you say I do is a lie.  And if we go to jail, I'll kill the children.  Jail is no place for little ones.
What little ones?  There are children there with you?
If you killed the little ones... wouldn't that also mean your own death?
(coolly)
We are all different people.
But when you get hurt...
I feel nothing.
Because Danny is the Keeper of Pain?
Exactly.  Danny is empath.
And Billy knows nothing about you?

He has amnesia.  Arthur and I keep him asleep to protect him. Depending on circumstances, either I rule or Arthur does.  In prison, I control spot because is dangerous place.  As protector, I have complete command.  In situations where is no danger, and where intelligence and logic are more important, then Arthur controls spot.
Do you know Tommy?
Of course.
He mentioned the spot, too.  Can you describe to us just what that means. Billy?... Uh... (he looks to Judy for help)
Ragen.

Ragen. But suddenly, RAGEN is gone.  JUDY and GARY look at each other.  There is none of the usual lips moving and quasi R.E.M. state.  He's just blank.  Then, in a moment, he "returns".  He seems tentative, frightened, softer.
Hello. No reply.
Have we met?  My name is Judy Stevenson.  This is Gary  Schweickart.  We're your attorneys. Do you have a name?
Judy. She looks at GARY.
His eyes. She looks back to BILLY.  His eyes seem to wander and dar back and forth of their own volition, like an ocular pendulum.
As GARY and JUDY come out.  GARY immediately lights a cigarette.
Either he's a multiple, or else he's the greatest liar anybody's ever seen.
Right.
The question is which is it?
(convinced)
Gary... As they talk, WE CUT TO: BILLY alone in his empty cell, eyes half-closed, lips moving silently.
He's facing hard time.
He's got one right handed personality.
Lots of people are ambidextrous.
Ragen speaks and writes prefect Serbo-Croation.
So do ten million Serbs.
Apparently, Arthur's fluent in Arabic and Swahili.
Having a facility for languages doesn't automatically make you one hand short for bridge.
The escape artist, the wandering eyes, the electronics expert... GARY and JUDY.
All of that can be mastered.

All by one person?  With a hundred I.Q.?  From a small farm in Ohio? You're looking for some kind of miraculous, inexplicable "thing" to prove this to you beyond a shadow of a doubt.  Well, it's an illness, Gary... not a magic trick.  And I believe him.
(sighs heavily)

I do, too.  And I feel like I can convince my wife of it when she asks me why I came down here for fifteen minutes, and came back five hours later.  But how in hell am I ever gonna convince a judge?  Or a prosecutor?  No one's ever been acquitted of a crime before by blaming it on another personality.
You won't have to.  He will.
BILLY sits on his cot in a cold sweat.  Something is clearly terrifying him.  He looks across the cell toward piece of steel over the sink shiny enough to serve as a mirror.  He is frozen.
It's a big, opaque, steel door with a small opening two thirds up in the middle.  A GUARD approaches with keys. There's a loud rumbling coming from inside.
Alright, Milligan.  Exercise time. As he turns the key:
One hour in the yard, all to yourself. As he opens the door:

Come on... Milligan... Now we see BILLY lying in a pool of blood on the floor. The sink is smashed into a million pieces and his wrists have been slashed lengthwise with a shard of porcelain. Hot water shoots from the blood-stained sink like a firehose gone haywire.  He meant business.  He's fainted and landed on his own arm, which is saving his life.  The GUARD runs in.
Help!  We got an emergency!  Quick!
BILLY lies in bed, staring off blankly, while GARY and JUDY talk to him.
How ya feelin', Billy?  You were out for quite some time.
Do you know where you are?  You're in the hospital, but you're gonna be just fine.  Your hearing is going to go ahead as scheduled.
Well, why don't you get some rest. We'll check in with you tomorrow.
Goodnight, Billy. He remains motionless.  They leave and we follow them int the hall.
What do you think?
I don't know.  But there were no hammers or crowbars in that cell with him.  He broke that sink with his bare fist.
MEMBERS OF THE ADULT PAROLE AUTHORITY, JUDY, BILLY and A PROSECUTOR, along with a COURT STENOGRAPHER and TWO POLIC OFFICERS.  BILLY'S wrists are bandaged.  GARY enters, obviously agitated.
(to Gary)
What's wrong?
I just found out they're gonna try and send him to jail for a parole violation and keep him there till the trial.  We need him in a hospital with doctors for those ninety days to build a case.
Parole violation?
But there's a statute of limitations and this is the last day they can nail him on it.
What are you gonna do?
Wing it.
(nods to the Prosecutor)
Mr. Yavitch?  Shall we begin?

Mr. Chairman, members of the Adult Parole Authority, the state moves that possession of an unregistered firearm is a direct violation of the defendant's parole, and he should therefore be remanded to Lebanon State Prison until trial date.
Objection, Mr. Chairman.
Mr. Schweickart -- don't you own a tie?
(disheveled as usual)
I do, your honor, but I like to save it for funerals.
What is your objection?
Are these the weapons that were found in the defendant's home?
Mr. Chairman, Mr. Schweickart knows damn well that they are.
Mr. Chairman, Mr. Schweickart does not know damn well that they are because Mr. Schweickart has yet to see any ballistics report.
The weapons have not been test fired yet, you honor, so the report has not been completed.  But I fail to see in what way that is prescient to the decision at hand.
(winging it)
It is "prescient" counsel, because without any proof of it's ability to propel a ballistic, this... "thing" is not a gun, your honor.
Oh come on, Schweickart, of course it's a gun. (to the Chairman)
It's a gun.  Obviously it's a gun. GARY grabs it and holds it to his head.
Mr. Schweickart... JUDY and BILLY duck -- the PROSECUTOR finches -- but GARY pulls the trigger.  It's unloaded.

Legally, until it shoots a bullet it's as much a gun as it is a zucchini.  And having zucchinis found in your apartment is not a violation of Mr. Milligan's or anybody else's parole.  Mr. Chairman, gentlemen, since the statute of limitations of Mr. Milligan's alleged parole violation is up today.  I move that the defendant be allowed to stay at Harding Hospital, under the supervision of a trained psychiatric staff until it is time for him to stand trial.
Mr. Chairman... The CHAIRMAN raps his gavel.
So be it.  Next time get your shit together, counsel. Shakes his head, chuckling.
Zucchinis...
BILLY is escorted from a police car by TWO UNIFORMED OFFICERS.  He is handcuffed.
An admitting nurse signs a release form, accepting delivery of BILLY with a big ORDERLY.
Take those off him.
Not while he's still ours. She finishes, they uncuff him.  To the nurse:
Can I give you a little advice? Keep him away from the toilets.  Let him piss in a bucket.
BILLY, the NURSE and the ORDERLY walking down the hall.
Doctor Harding's not here right now, but he'll look in on you as soon as he arrives. As they walk, they pass people who are obviously deeply disturbed, as well as TWO FEMALE PSYCH-TECHS.
(after they've passed)
I'm not gonna stand for it.
Jean...
It's a con.  It's a lousy con.  And I'm not gonna treat him.
BILLY is alone.  He looks at the door.  An eye is watchin him through the peephole.
A PSYCH-TECH sits on a stool, watching him and taking notes.
5:00 Sitting cross legged on bed, quiet. 5:15 Sitting cross legged on bed, staring. 5:32 Standing, looking out the window.
BILLY sits, alone and sullen, while other PATIENTS either smoke, play cards or stare into space.  Another YOUNG MAL PATIENT sits next to him.  He's got a tin of peanut brittle.
Want some?  My folks bring it.  Your folks come visit you?
My folks are divorced.  Leave me alone.
What's your name?  Come on, what's your name?
Allen.
(sympathetic)
Only they call you Billy, right? But that's not your name, is it?  I understand.
(softening)
You do?
They do that all the time here. (offers his hand)
Natalie Wood.  How do you do? BILLY shakes it.
At Harding Hospital.  BILLY attached to an EEG, while a TECHNICIAN looks at the results.  He's obviously confused
on the print out.
At Harding.  The TECHNICIAN is showing the printout to a DOCTOR.
It's got to be a mistake.  A glitch in the machine.
I've never had a problem before.
Well, what do you want me to say? Adults do not emit spiked Theta waves on their EEG's.  Only children do.  Try changing the electrode.
The TWO DOCTORS are administering another EEG to BILLY. They seem satisfied with the results this time.
See?  Completely normal.  Those electrodes are for shit.
But I didn't change the electrode. I had to order it.
DOCTOR HARDING approaches BILLY'S peephole and peers in. Beside him is the ADMITTING NURSE.
BILLY is on the floor, drawing.  He's made a very disturbing picture of a tombstone that's inscribed: DO NO R.I.P.
I think he's looking forward to meeting you, Doctor.
(gulps a little)
I'll see him in my office.  Lots of coffee, please. He heads off down the hall.
BILLY is dropped off by an ORDERLY.
(rises to greet him)
Ah, Billy, come on in.  Sit down. Coffee? The ORDERLY leaves, closing the door and shutting us out.
It's small and sterile.  The JUDGE, PROSECUTOR, STENOGRAPHER, DR. HARDING, GARY, JUDY and BILLY are present.

Your honor, based on my interviews with the defendant, it is my opinion that, William S. Milligan suffers from Multiple Personality Disorder and has fragmented into ten separate personality manifestations.  At the time of the acts in question, I believe he was mentally ill and unable to distinguish between right and wrong.  Further, he did not have the ability to refrain from committing these acts.  These findings are consistent with a plea of not guilty by reason of insanity, and I would, therefore, recommend that he be remanded to Athens State Hospital for suitable treatment.
Mr. Yavitch, do you contest these findings?
No, your honor.  The prosecution does not.
Then, lacking any evidence to the contrary, this court has no alternative than to find the defendant not guilty by reason of insanity. He raps his gavel three times.
BILLY is led, handcuffed, by TWO POLICEMEN, out a back entrance, but they still collide with a handful of REPORTERS.
How do you feel now that you've been found not guilty?
I feel better now that it's all over with and I finally have come back to a reality that I've missed for so long.
Do you have any recollection of the crimes your other personalities have been charged with?
Very little.  Certain things come to me in forms of dreams that you could call memories, but I can't really distinct between memories -- the realities...
(aside to another Reporter)
Yeah, right.  And I'm Doris Day.
... because my emotions split so far apart -- love, hate and fear...
Billy, what do you want to do with your life?
Become a citizen again. The COPS lead him away.
BILLY sits in back, flanked by the TWO POLICEMEN.  It's freezing cold.  They're bundled up -- BILLY wears just a suit.  One POLICEMAN drinks hot coffee.
Well, you got away with it, didn't ya?  You must be pretty proud of yourself. BILLY shivers silently.
You turn my stomach.  I've got two daughters.  Come on, you can tell me -- you're fakin', right?
Ray... (to Billy)

You look cold.  You want some hot coffee?  Here. The SECOND POLICEMAN, who wears thick gloves, purposely shoves the cup at BILLY'S handcuffed hands so that the coffee spills all over his lap, scalding him.  The POLICEMEN laugh. Out the window, BILLY realizes they're passing by a turn off on the road marked by a covered bridge.  He gets upset. WE PRESS IN on BILLY.  Then:

location: THE SHOWROOM AT THE EDEN ROC HOTEL IN MIAMI BEACH

text: It's 1958, and filled with middle aged JEWISH COUPLES out for the resort's Saturday night entertainment.  The MEN are in suits and the WOMEN are dressed to the teeth -- falls attached to over-teased hair, false eyelashes and stiff, heavy gowns.  Minks draped over chairbacks. Spotlights roam the stage and the audience.

Ladies and gentlemen.  The Eden Roc Hotel welcomes you to the Grand Ballroom.  Have we got a show for you tonight! PRESS IN on BILLY, AGE THREE. He's in a suit and bowtie, on a stool next to the kitchen entrance, watching the stage in rapt fascination.  WAITER and BUSBOYS rush past him loaded down with trays full of drinks.
Claire and Myrna -- the Barry Sisters... (applause)
The dancing stylings of Tanya and Briaggi... (applause)
And now, please welcome the adults only comedy of Johnny Morrison.

Over applause, the band plays JOHNNY'S lead-in music.  He bounds on stage, all sweat and smiles -- his old shirt collar too tight for his extra chin.  But the spotlights keep roaming -- leaving him in the dark.  He gives a "can you believe this shit?" face and the audience reluctantly plays along.  This is the oldest shtick in the book.  Onc again, the band plays his little intro.  Once again the audience applauds -- but less than before.  And this time instead of the spots landing on him at the music cut-off, they focus on an empty spot across the stage.  Scattered laughter.  More groans.
laughing hard.
Now you know why it's cheaper here than the Fountainbleu. Nothing.  No response.  Just chairs scuffling and forks o dessert plates.
Between BILLY and the SPOTLIGHT, as JOHNNY continues with his act.  BILLY is fascinated by it: it's sharp, defined glow, lighting up just one perfect circle while all aroun it is darkness.

Two women at the Fountainbleu are looking through a hole in the wall into the men's steam room.  They see one poor shnook, naked as a jaybird with a towel over his face. The first woman says: "Ciel... would you look at that?  He's not Jewish." The other woman says "Jewish?  He's not even a guest here." Rimshot.
(flop sweat now)

Alright, already. He whistles at the spot through his two fingers and motions it towards him.  It moves maybe a foot in his direction.  He commits the comic's cardinal sin -- he laughs when the audience doesn't.  He's the joke now.
oblivious.  Laughing -- deliriously happy.  Suddenly, a BUSBOY with a tray full of glasses bangs into him and everything smashes to the ground.
(cleaning)
Goddammit!
I'm sorry.
Get out of the goddamn aisle.  I been just missin' you all night.
I couldn't see before.
Well, that's too bad -- what the hell are you doin' in here all alone, anyway?
(points to Johnny)
That's my Daddy.
Yeah?  Well, he stinks.  That steam room joke is as old as my Aunt Bessie's ass. He goes to lift BILLY off the stool.
Now sit someplace else, before I have you thrown out.
No! TWO BIG HANDS -- more like paws -- enter frame and lift the BUSBOY off the ground.  They belong to a second BUSBOY, huge and mustachioed.  He speaks with a thick Slavic accent.
Leave him alone.
(scared)
Hey, buddy, I was only...
Just leave him alone. He tosses the FIRST BUSBOY aside like a piece of crumpled up paper and gives his attention to BILLY.
I couldn't see before.  That's my Daddy. He lifts BILLY up onto his shoulders.
There.  Now you see everything.
as JOHNNY finally walks over to the spot and steps inside it.  A couple of people applaud.
on the BUSBOY'S shoulders -- eyes glued to his FATHER -- all lit up against the blackness.

BILLY'S MOTHER, DOROTHY, is coming, watching a soap opera and talking on the phone all at the same time.  BILLY, still three, has a toy ambulance that he's running all over with -- rolling it over everything, making siren noises, "vrooming" at the top of his lungs.  Finally:

Billy, please -- can't you see I'm tryin' to watch the TV?  Now take that someplace else. He takes the car down the hall -- vrooming slightly quieter.  WE HOLD on a framed photo of JOHNNY MORRISON an JIMMY DURANTE.  Baby BILLY sits on DURANTE'S knee.

arrives at a door leading to the garage.  He opens it and immediately starts coughing.  It's filled with fumes.  He looks inside the car, which is running, and sees his FATHER, slumped over on the front seat.

It's filled with people, all in black, all eating.  BILLY is in a black suit and bowtie, getting underneath everybody's feet, still carrying his ambulance.  He vroom very quietly.  He looks over at his MOTHER, red-eyed from crying, on a sofa with another WOMAN.  DOROTHY breaks down.
My God, he looks just like him.  I can't look at him.  I can't... THE OTHER WOMAN quickly bustles BILLY away.
Come on, son.  Your Mother's very upset.
It's empty as the WOMAN brings BILLY inside.

Now you just sit up here and play for a while, alright?  That's all grown up stuff goin' on downstairs. And soon your Mama's gonna take you back home with her to Ohio.  Won't that be fun? She leaves and closes the door.  He sits alone in the middle of the floor.  He spins the wheels of his ambulanc against the worn out rug.
(softly, a siren)
Wooooo... woooo... And he rolls it slowly out of frame.  Beat... beat... beat... it rolls back to him.  And it's been turned aroun to face him.  BILLY looks up and smiles.
to reveal a three year old GIRL, all in white.  She's the girl from the painting with the rag doll.
Vrooom... vrooom...
He rolls it back to her.

There's a piano bar and DOROTHY is in a ratty, red sequined dress, singing "You're Nobody Till Somebody Love You." As she does, WE SEE BILLY, age eight, not really watching, just sitting sullenly -- blowing air bubbles in his Coke.  Someone's watching though.  CHALMER MILLIGAN sits at the bar, smiling at DOROTHY.  She starts performing just to him.  BILLY realizes what's going on and watches carefully.  CHALMER catches BILLY'S look and feels exposed.  He turns his attention back to DOROTHY.
CHALMER and DOROTHY, laughing in a booth over drinks.
to the next booth -- BILLY is fast asleep.
Lots of people and rides.  BILLY, DOROTHY and CHALMER are in line for one ride, but as they get to the gate:
Sorry, he's too little.  There's a height requirement. BILLY is stricken.
(to Billy)
Well, tell ya what -- you wait here and we'll meet you right after. It's a short one, this one. He ushers DOROTHY onto the ride as BILLY steps aside -- watching and waiting.

CHALMER watches from the sofa as BILLY sits with crayons and a pad on the floor.  BILLY reaches for the red one, but CHALMER'S foot comes down on it.  A beat as BILLY looks up at him.  Finally, CHALMER lifts his foot and BILLY takes it.
DOROTHY is shaking BILLY out of a deep sleep.  She's breathless with excitement.
Billy, wake up.  Look. She shows him an engagement ring on her finger.
He asked me to marry him.  We're not going to be alone anymore. She hugs him tight.
BILLY and DOROTHY doing the dishes together.
I don't know what to call him.

Chalmer is your Daddy, now.  You call him Daddy Chal. BILLY looks into the living room at CHALMER, asleep in front of the TV, a beer in his hand.  CHALMER opens his eyes unexpectedly, startling BILLY.
What are you doin' in there?  Only sissies help their Mama's do dishes. You come in here with me and watch some TV. BILLY is nervous.
(privately)
Go on.  He's you Daddy, now.  You mind him.  He loves you. BILLY goes inside.
The three of them at the dinner table.  No talking -- jus quiet eating.
Billy, would you please pass the salt? He grabs it and goes to hand it to his MOTHER, but CHALME grabs his other wrist.
Salt gets passed clockwise.
What?
Everything at the table gets passed clockwise.
Why?

Because that's how we did it when I was growin' up.  It learned me manners -- you don't have everybody reachin' all over the table for everything -- gettin' in everybody's food. BILLY passes it clockwise, via CHALMER, who gives it to DOROTHY.
Thank you.

It's just like when I taught you to sit with your hands on your knees and your feet flat on the floor when you're not eatin'.  And you don't have to know the reason for everything, anyway.  If I say to do something, then that's enough. Right?
Yes.
Yes, what?
Yes, Daddy Chal.
CHALMER, BILLY and DOROTHY watching TV.  Ed Sullivan. CHALMER'S got a beer in one hand and his other arm is around DOROTHY as he starts fondling her breast.
(smiling awkwardly, pulling away)
Chalmer...
(a hoarse whisper)
What...? He leans in to kiss her neck.  BILLY watches.  CHALMER looks right at him, then nuzzles her.
(still mindful of decorum)
No...
(climbing on her now, but not really threatening)
Don't tell me no -- we're married now. He thinks he's being playful.  A hand inside her blouse. BILLY still watches in silence.
(catches Billy's look to Chalmer)
Billy...
So? He looks at BILLY once more, then, never taking his eyes off him, slides his tongue into DOROTHY'S ear.
(gets up)
We can go in the bedroom. She leaves and goes upstairs.  BILLY looks at CHALMER.
What are you looking at? (an icy hiss)

You bend them eyes while I'm talkin' to you, boy. BILLY looks down.  CHALMER drains his beer and tosses the empty can at him, then heads upstairs.  In a moment, we hear a hit.  DOROTHY screams.  Another hit.  BILLY sits closer to the TV -- turns up the volume.  A plate spinner on Ed Sullivan.  As the beating continues upstairs.  BILL changes the channel, landing on an old Basil Rathbone/Nigel Bruce Sherlock Holmes movie.  He stare har as Holmes performs some miraculous demonstration of deduction.  BILLY turns up the volume till it drowns everything else out.
BILLY sits drawing at the table while his MOTHER does the ironing.  The drawing is a landscape, and remarkably good for a nine year old.

Is it that late?  God, I don't know where the time went. She leaves the room and heads upstairs.  As BILLY looks up, he sees CHALMER standing in the next room, staring at him.  BILLY goes back to drawing, but is unnerved.  He looks up again -- CHALMER is gone.  He tentatively leaves the kitchen and pads very slowly into the living room.  N one there.  BILLY sits on the sofa and looks up -- there' CHALMER, leaning against the wall next to the entrance way.  BILLY is startled.

Hello, Daddy Chal... No response.  CHALMER'S eyes bore a hole right through th boy.  BILLY picks up a magazine.  He leaf's through a couple of pages, consumed with fright, then puts it back carefully -- perfectly -- in the center of the coffee table.  He glances up.  CHALMER hasn't moved.  He's still staring.  BILLY puts his hands on his knees and his feet flat on the floor.  Then he gets up and exits the room from the opposite side where CHALMER is.

As BILLY comes out of the house.  He goes into the yard and wanders restlessly -- tosses a stick.  He gathers all his courage and looks back towards the house.  There is CHALMER, watching him from the window.  Terrified, BILLY starts to cry silently.  Suddenly, his MOTHER'S voice startles him.
Billy! She's at the upstairs window.
Come on to bed!
BILLY lies awake.  He's exhausted, but more scared.  Ever time he starts to nod off, he forces his eyes back open with a start.  He pinches his arm and twists hard to keep himself up.
BILLY, eyes puffy from lack of sleep, sits opposite CHALMER and DOROTHY.  CHALMER doesn't look like he's slep much, either.
Look what I made for my two men this morning.  Pancakes and bacon and fresh squeezed juice...
We're going to the farm today, Billy.  There's a lot to be done. BILLY is gripped by fear.
BILLY and CHALMER moving down a long, lonely road. Neither one says a word.  They both just stare straight ahead.

As it turns off one road and onto another -- this one containing the covered bridge.  It's the same one that adult BILLY passed in the police car.  A farm can be seen in the distance amongst the spindly, leafless trees.
CHALMER sits on the ground, drinking beer and staring.
to include the corn crib from the charcoal animation. BILLY is locked inside, trying to ignore his step-father' stare.

BILLY sees a cardinal on a tree branch.  He has some paints with him and starts to sketch out the bird on a piece of slate.  Suddenly CHALMER pops up in front of him carrying a shovel.  He unlocks the corn crib.
Come on... He leads BILLY out and they walk off into a field as the cardinal flies away to freedom.
BILLY is digging a long hole that's already knee deep. CHALMER sits and watches.  He holds a rusty, hollow, meta pipe in his hand -- about a foot long and four inches wide.
Six feet.  You hear me? BILLY continues digging.

CHALMER pushes a rototiller, churning up the ground for the coming season. WE FOLLOW him as he goes.  Finally, he passes the pipe he was holding earlier -- only now it sticks up six inches from the ground.  As CHALMER rides out of frame we hear the amplified sound of shallow breathing.

We see BILLY only from the naked torso up.  Through a window, we can see CHALMER outside, drinking under a tree His pants are undone.  BILLY'S back is to us.  He's tied to the rototiller -- straddling it.  His eyes are wet from crying.  He struggles against the rope, but it's no use.  Then, his eyes fix into the middle distance.  He stares so hard, it hurts.
shining straight into our eyes.  At first it has no form, no perimeters.
staring.

feels like a birth as we PULL BACK from its center, gathering velocity.  It rumbles, then roars, until we finally get to it's outer edge.  Now it has a shape.  It' a spotlight -- sharp, defined.  Surrounded by darkness. Like the spot that shone on Johnny Morrison at the Eden Roc.
staring even harder.
as a form emerges from it's deepest recesses.  It's human A teenage boy.  The figure stretches out it's hand.

Suddenly, he blinks -- like we've seen the adult BILLY do.  His entire face seems to change.  He's not terrified anymore, merely confused.  He reaches his face over to hi constrained hand and touches his cheek with his fingers. He has no idea why he's been crying.  He looks around the barn -- then out at CHALMER, who is oblivious.  BILLY looks at the rope around his wrists.  They are tied to each other, close together, but there's still some slack. He takes a beat, then uses one hand to push the thumb of his other hand far across it palm.  His eyes are clenched in concentration.  His hand turns beet red.  Suddenly, there's a snap and his thumb is successfully dislocated. With his thumb pulled out of its socket and draped across his palm, the thickest part of his hand is now thinner than his wrist, enabling him to slide it out from the rope.  He snaps it back in place and undoes his other wrist.  Outside the window, CHALMER is now passed out drunk.

THE CARDINAL painted on the piece of slate.  It's been signed: BILLY.  BILLY is fully dressed now, rubbing his still red thumb, when he stumbles upon it.  He picks up the paintbrush next to it and adds some touches. Satisfied, he signs a second name beneath the one that's already there: TOMMY.

It's a brilliant Fall day.  BILLY, age nine, is walking t school past an apple orchard.  He carries a big, shiny re apple -- polishing it as he goes.  He never sees the car that suddenly rounds the bend and heads straight for him. We hear a MAN and a WOMAN giggling drunkenly from inside -- completely oblivious.  It is virtually upon him, when, as if shoved from behind by an invisible force, BILLY is thrown clear of the automobile.  It crushes the apple int sauce and disappears around the next bend, but BILLY land safely.  He starts to cry.  Then we hear a voice.  It has a thick East European accent.
Christene... BILLY looks up.
Please... don't cry... I get you another apple.
on a adult pair of hands as they shimmy up a tree trunk and grab an apple.
BILLY, holding this new apple, walking happily to school once more.
against a dark and indistinct background.  He's inspired by the Eden Roc busboy -- intense, olive-skinned, with a full black moustache.
I will always be here to protect you.

BILLY, age twenty one, is working out with a set of nunchuks.  He handles them like an expert, like a killer. Sweat covers his bare chest.  His hands are a blur.  He punctuates each move with a throaty war cry, still in the thick Yugoslavian accent, as he uses a mannequin's face and torso to simulate the disarming and vicious pummeling of an attacker.  He ends with a fierce, sustained scream of a warrior.  When he comes back to himself, he looks down: the mannequin is in shreds.  He opens the refrigerator.  It's empty.  He grabs his wallet from his pocket and opens it.  It's empty.  He throws it angrily t the floor.  He goes to the sink and sticks his head under to wash the sweat off the get a drink, when the doorbell rings.  BILLY approaches it warily.  He keeps his accent all through this.
Who is it?

Gordy. BILLY grabs an M-16 from under a chair, reaches high on a shelf for a clip and pops it in, then holds it to his sid as he opens the door a few inches.  GORDY is eighteen, thin, pale and high as a kite.
Shit, it's cold.  You got any scotch? He starts to enter, but BILLY blocks his way.

What's wrong?  We gonna do this in front of the neighbors?  I've got the money. GORDY takes out sixty bucks in crumpled bills.  BILLY looks at it, then lets him in.  GORDY walks past him into the living room.
Where are you going?
(not looking back, imitates him)
Where am I going? GORDY pulls out a dresser drawer and put it on the floor.

Hey. GORDY reaches in and BILLY moves right for him, the gun barrel coming to rest on his back.  GORDY pulls out a cellophane bag that's been duck taped to the back of the dresser.  It's got several smaller bags inside, each stocked with a different supply of pills.
Whoa.  Jackpot. He turns and sees the gun pointed straight at him.
What's wrong?  I showed you the money. He tosses it to BILLY.
Cool it. But BILLY is stunned.  He's never seen the pills before. He lowers his gun and grabs the bag.  As he opens it and pulls out its contents:
What are you gettin' all excited for?  Have I ever ripped you off? Never.  Wow, you got the reds. BILLY drops the bag to the floor.
How did you know this was there?
(picking them up)

That's where you always keep 'em. Oh no.  Are you gonna get all weird again?  I hate when you do this shit. GORDY pockets sixty dollars worth of speed, then sees the nunchuks and a set of free weights.
I didn't know you were so into that stuff. He picks up the nunchuks -- does a few comically inane moves.
Put them down.
(he does)

Boy, who put the bug up your ass today?  And what's with the commie accent?  You know, the guy I work for is looking for a bodyguard. Someone to drive the car to the pick-ups and look like an animal so no one pulls any shit.  You wanna meet him?  The pay is good.
How much?
I don't know -- ask him.  The sumbitch is made of money.  I'm goin' over there now.  You wanna come?
We need money.
So come on.  His name's Foley. BILLY grabs a sweatshirt and they leave.

As the water roars below, BILLY sits alone in his parked car.  Thirty yards away is a parked MERCEDES.  TWO MEN si in the front seat, while GORDY leans in the back window talking to FOLEY.  BILLY is tense, but stoic.  In a moment, GORDY turns.  He gets out of the car.

He wants to talk to you. BILLY gets out of the car.  The other THREE MEN get out o theirs.  BILLY takes the long walk over, but upon reachin them one MAN spins him around to face the car while holding an automatic to his head and the OTHER starts to frisk him. You.  Take gun from under jacket with two fingers and put on ground.    The MAN hesitates.

Vodka.

GORDY'S taking a hit of speed and washing it down with a swig of vodka.

You O.K.? (holds out the speed)

Gordy. BILLY smiles and takes a pill.  After he swallows it, GORDY offers him the vodka.  BILLY reaches past him for a beer. GORDY shrugs and picks up a volume of poetry by Emily Dickinson.

I've never seen it before.

He's nine years old.  DOROTHY'S approaching voice wakes him up.

The bright, white light, surrounded by darkness.  PHIL is there, tucking a napkin into his collar.  He's a tough looking twenty year old with bad skin and three days of growth of beard.

throwing a rock and shattering a window.

Kevin.

picking up a rock.

L.S.D.  Kevin and Philip have become undesirables.  Something must be done to banish them from the spot.

MUSIC blasts.  Elton John's "Madman Across the Water". The screen is filled with a wash of deep blue.  BILLY enters frame, silhouetted against it, paintbrush in hand. ALLEN painting.  Cigarette dangling from his mouth.
further along.  It's like a story unfolding.  Symbols, clocks, faces -- all corresponding to some private vision of BILLY'S.

TIME CUT.  BILLY is drenched now.  He paints a section, then steps back to look at it.  Dissatisfied he takes a can of red paint and flings it across the canvas. He sees the bag of drugs ARTHUR had left out earlier and picks them up, hungrily.  From out of an envelope, he shakes ou a small piece of paper with a stamp of a loopy cartoon horse on it. painting -- tripping out of his mind.

painting in detail once more.  His neck is sore.  His fingers are sore.  It's pitch black outside.

finally finished.  Ashtray overflowing.  He's looking at the result.  It is a major work -- complicated -- probabl over-complicated -- full of the confusion and enormity of what's inside him. to include the spot in the distance.  RAGEN is in it.  In the foreground, now, the lurking male figure enters the frame.  We see him, only partially and from behind, watching RAGEN.

playing chess.  CHRISTENE drawing in the spot in the background.

We'll make rules.  Everyone will have specific duties that are tailored toward their particular talents.  Tommy is an electronics genius, as well as an escape artist. Several of us are painters.  I excel at foreign languages and dabble in medicine and biochemistry.  The girls do domestic chores.

... developing yourself physically... learning the martial arts -- weaponry -- being able to step into a dangerous situation at a moments notice. He speeds up -- running harder and harder. to include class.  They are all staring at BILLY, age fourteen, who sits at his desk, eyes glazed and half rolled into his head -- lips moving a mile a minute -- whispering in a strange gibberish.

I see a woman falling down and suddenly she's turning into a pile of metal and I can't reach her and I'm so scared and lonely and I'm afraid to ask for help.  I need help.  Oh God... Hey, I'm the only kid who can take a trip without LSD.

BILLY being examined by a G.P. -- while his MOTHER looks on.  After a bit:

Go on, Billy, you mind the doctor. The DOCTOR reaches for BILLY'S belt, and BILLY screams in terror.
Nooo!!! It echoes into eternity as WE CUT TO:
BILLY walking down a corridor with a different DOCTOR, leaving his MOTHER behind.  As they go, they pass all manner of disturbed children.
Don't worry, Billy.  No one's going to hurt you.  We're here to help you.
The DOCTOR gives BILLY two pills in a small, paper container.  BILLY puts them in his mouth.
BILLY taking different pills on a different day. The same day. And again.  Now he washes them down with water.
BILLY, DOROTHY and CHALMER, across the desk from the DOCTOR.

He certainly seems high strung, and his mood swings are unpredictable. He also likes to pretend or role play quite a bit.  But I don't really see that there's anything more we can do for him here.  Try changing his diet.  He seems to do better on Jello day.
As BILLY walks through with his books, other KIDS point and whisper to each other.  Some laugh.  As he passes one little GIRL, she yells from behind.
Billy Milligan is a psycho!  He was in the loony bin! The KIDS laugh.

Which is now occupied by ALLEN, the fourteen year old, al alone in the light.  His confused expression is an exact duplicate of BILLY'S on the roof.  Somewhere in the B.G., a small girl laughs softly.
into the surrounding semi-darkness, where RAGEN kneels before CHRISTENE, a finger to his lips.

MEN duck and weave in goggles an huge, rubber gloves, narrowly avoiding decapitation or electrocution as they do their routines.
standing at the operator's control panel.  It's a mystifying series of buttons, levers and speakers -- and BILLY is completely dumbfounded.

as suddenly there's a zinc stack up in one of the acetone rinses.  The parts keep rolling along on the overhead conveyor track -- compounding the jam.

knows he's yelling at him, but hasn't any idea what he's supposed to do.  He sees the WORKER'S lips move.

Right smack in the middle of a party.  Lots of people dancing, drinking, making small talk.  We pick out BILLY, sitting on a sofa next to FRANCINE.  She's unselfconsciously beautiful.  Her edge is tough. Unpampered.  But not without its sweetness.  BILLY looks lost beside her.
You O.K.?
Yeah, fine.
I kept sayin' "Billy".  Did you hear me?

(flirting a little)

I like girls to be a little slutty.

Where you make your eyes go funny.

Me?  What about you? He looks at the beer in his hand, not knowing how it got there, and not feeling the least bit drunk.

You said you'd show me your paintings.  Come on, I wanna see 'em.  I'll just say goodnight to Liz. She gets up and crosses to her girlfriend.  BILLY sits there and fades away into himself. (English accent)
I'm perfectly fine.
(laughing, and doing an  English accent)

four or five, one after the other.  Landscapes, portraits...
looking at them with BILLY.

to include FRANCINE, in his oversized tee shirt, silently looking around the apartment.  It's fairly run down and cheaply furnished.  There is a conspicuous absence of photographs. (sharply)

A minute?  It's almost dawn.  Come on back to bed. She leads him.  As they lie down, she kisses him.  She pulls away.

He sits at his desk, translating Arabic from a thick hardcover.  As he moves the book closer, a note falls out It says: You have hidden talents.  - F.  BILLY crumples i up angrily, then feels something in his pocket.  He reaches in and pulls out an empty condom wrapper.  He throws it in the trash.
(English accent)
She spent the night.  Bloody hell.
BILLY scrubs himself, singing, feeling good.
BILLY, in his jacket, grabs his lunch pail and heads out the door.
BILLY driving, singing along with the radio.
As BILLY pulls up.
In full operation.  The belly of the beast.  BILLY walks in, happy as a clam.  A couple of GUYS look at him funny.
(nods)

Roy.  Leaky. He makes his way to the makeshift locker area: there are boxes in rows attached to a wall, facing out.  Each one has a name written on masking tape. A continuation of the earlier shot: BILLY walks aimlessly
The lids aren't on them because they're not dead yet.
A DOCTOR, in a suit and white lab coat, is hitting BILLY with a Bible as he's held down by ATTENDANTS.
I rebuke you demons, in the name of the savior, Jesus Christ!  Leave this wretched soul!
They're asleep, waiting for something.  There are some empty coffins because not everyone has come there yet.

BILLY continues walking.  He reaches a MEN'S ROOM and looks in.  The toilets are stainless steel.  He shifts hi gaze.  The MAN who refuses his Thorazine is running the sink water at a boiling hot temperature.  He looks at BILLY through the steam.

Danny and the other young ones want a chance at life.  The older ones have given up hope. The MAN puts his finger under the water -- never taking his eyes off BILLY.  The flesh quickly bubbles and boils off.
Danny named this place because he made it. The MAN brings what's left of his digit to his mouth and bites it off.
He calls it "The Dying Place".

A GUARD throws in some paints, a brush and a piece of paper, then leaves.  BILLY picks up the paintbrush, but sets the paper aside.  He turns to the white wall and starts a mural.  It begins to segue into the Rotoscope animation -- then flowing once more into reality as it charts the accelerated progress of the painting.  Back an forth, until it's become a lush, green landscape. Idyllic, lyrical. WE PRESS IN on BILLY, in both reality and animation, as h paints, until we can no longer see the room around him -- just BILLY, enveloped in this peaceful, green Eden -- painting himself out of Hell and into a world of escape.

Gary Schweickart appealed Billy Milligan's case to the Supreme Court.  On December 4, 1980, he was returned to Athens State Hospital, where he was successfully fused. Lima State Hospital was closed soon afterwards, amid indictments for patient abuse.

text: Today, after thirteen years in the Ohio Mental Health System.  Billy Milligan is a free man and supporting himself as an artist.
